title: CP9 Used Their Real Names During Undercover Mission
theory: Despite being on a top-secret five-year undercover mission, the CP9 agents infiltrating Water 7 used their actual real names - Rob Lucci, Kaku, Kalifa, and Blueno. This is particularly strange for Rob Lucci, whose name was already infamous in the One Piece world for killing 500 soldiers of a kingdom at age 13. The theory questions why no one at Galley-La Company, including the well-connected Iceburg, ever suspected or recognized that 'Rob Lucci the shipwright' might be the same Rob Lucci who was notorious for that massacre. This raises questions about CP9's infiltration methods and whether they were overconfident, whether the World Government had suppressed information about Lucci's appearance, or whether Oda hadn't fully planned out Lucci's backstory when creating the Water 7 arc.
author: Various Worstgen Forum users
supportingEvidence: Rob Lucci's name was known to powerful figures like Bartholomew Kuma, who referenced him by name at Thriller Bark
Lucci had killed 500 soldiers at age 13, which should have been a notorious incident
The CP9 agents spent five years in Water 7 without changing their names
Iceburg and the Galley-La Company had connections throughout the world but never made the connection
counterArguments: The World Government may have suppressed visual information about CP9 agents to protect their identities
Rob Lucci may be a common enough name in the One Piece world that it wouldn't immediately raise suspicion
The incident with the 500 soldiers may not have been widely publicized beyond government circles
CP9's confidence in their cover identities may have been justified by the World Government's ability to erase or obscure their true backgrounds
communityReaction: The theory has generated discussion among fans about whether this represents a plot hole or a calculated risk by CP9. Some fans argue it demonstrates CP9's extreme confidence in their abilities, while others see it as a minor oversight in the story's planning.

title: Oda Originally Didn't Plan for Lucci to be CP9
theory: According to statements from Eiichiro Oda, Rob Lucci was not originally intended to be part of CP9 during the early development of the Water 7 Saga. The theory suggests that Lucci may have been planned as just a regular, skilled shipwright before Oda evolved the story to make him the primary antagonist of the arc. This would explain some of the seeming plot holes around his identity and why his character seemed so naturally integrated into the Galley-La Company before the reveal. The theory explores how Oda's evolving story planning may have led to the shocking betrayal being even more effective because Lucci was genuinely written as a normal character before being reimagined as the villain.
author: Based on Oda's statements, discussed by fans
supportingEvidence: Oda has confirmed that Lucci was not originally planned to be part of CP9
Lucci's character is extremely well-integrated into the Galley-La Company, suggesting he was written as a genuine member
The betrayal feels organic rather than forced, which would be consistent with a character who was originally planned differently
Early Water 7 episodes show Lucci as a background character without obvious villain hints
counterArguments: Oda is known for long-term planning, so the change may have occurred early in the arc's development
The seamless integration could also be credited to Oda's writing skill rather than a change in plans
Oda may have been speaking about very early planning stages before the arc was fully developed
communityReaction: This revelation has been well-received by fans as it provides insight into Oda's creative process and explains why Lucci's betrayal felt so genuine and shocking. Many fans appreciate learning about how the story evolved during development.
